translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Discourse on the Arrow🔽The life of mortals here is unknown,

analyzed: a nimittam an aññāta  matcānam idha jīvita
translated: unsignaled,
And it is short and limited,
and bound up with suffering.
There is no way at all
by which those born will not die;
Even having reached old age, death is
for living beings, such is the nature of things.
Just as for fruits that are ripe,
there is the danger of falling down;
So for those mortals who are born,
there is always the danger of death.

analyzed: yathā api kumbhakārassa  katā mattika bhājanā
translated: Just as for the potter🔽the clay vessels are all subject to breaking;
So for mortals, life is
subject to breaking.
Whether young or old,
whether foolish or wise;
All go under the sway of death,
all are subject to death.
For those who are subject to death,
going from this world to the next;
The father does not protect the son,

original: ñātī vā pana ñātake.🔽Pekkhataṁyeva ñātīnaṁ,🔽passa lālapataṁ puthu;
analyzed: ñātī vā pana ñātake  pekkhatayā iva ñātīna  passa lālapatam puthu
translated: nor the relatives the relatives.🔽Just looking on at the relatives,🔽see the many who are crying;
Mortals are led away
like a cow to the slaughter.
Thus the world is struck down
by death and old age;
Therefore the wise do not grieve,
Knowing the world’s passing away.
If you do not know the path

analyzed: āgatassa gatassa vā  ubho ante a sampassa
translated: Of one who has come or gone,🔽Not seeing both ends,
You grieve without purpose.
If, grieving,🔽You would attain some purpose,🔽The wise would do it,
But confused, you would only harm yourself.
For through weeping and grieving
One does not attain peace of mind.
Suffering increases
And the body wastes away.

original: Kiso vivaṇṇo bhavati,🔽Hiṁsamattānamattanā;🔽Na tena petā pālenti,
analyzed: kisaḥ vivaṇṇaḥ bhavati  hisamatta anamattanā  na tena petā pālenti
translated: One becomes thin and pale,🔽Harming oneself for no reason.🔽The dead are not protected
By the grieving.

analyzed: sokam appajaham jantu  bhiyyas dukkham nigacchati
translated: A person who abandons grief🔽Enters even more suffering.
Not consenting to death,
One comes under the sway of sorrow.

analyzed: aññe pi passa gamine  yathā kammupage nare
translated: See also other people going🔽According to their kamma.
Having come under the sway of death,
Beings tremble in various ways.
Whatever they imagine
Turns out to be otherwise.
Such is separation:
See the world’s passing away.
Even if one lives a hundred years,
Or even more than that, young brahmin,
One’s circle of relatives is lost,
And one loses one’s life here.
Therefore, having heard the one who is accomplished,
Having restrained one’s lamenting,
Having seen that this one has died,
‘This is not to be obtained by me.’
Just as one would extinguish a blazing fire
With water,
So too, the wise one, the one with discernment,
The wise person, the skilled one,
Quickly destroys the arisen sorrow,
Like the wind a tuft of cotton.
Lamentation and weeping,🔽And one’s own grief,

analyzed: attanaḥ sukham esānaḥ  ap bahe salla mattano
translated: Seeking one’s own happiness,🔽One draws out one’s own dart.
Having drawn out the dart, being unattached,
Having attained peace of mind,
Having gone beyond all sorrow,

analyzed: a sokaḥ hoti nibbuto ti 🔽salla suttam aṭṭhama
translated: One is without sorrow, extinguished.🔽The eighth discourse on the dart.
